headline: 1 Way the Magnificent 7 Stocks Disappointed in 2024
summary: The group—which boasts  Apple Nvidia Microsoft Alphabet Amazon.com Meta Platforms  and  Tesla  —averaged a gain of 65% this year, compared with an average of 111% last year, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  The good news: That means other stocks had a chance to perform well, and names like  Palantir Technologies Vistra Walmart AppLovin  and  MicroStrategy  found themselves as top performers.  “The stalwart cloud/hyper scale players in 2025 will continue to play an instrumental role in this key phase of the AI Revolution being led by Microsoft and now also seeing Google (  GCP  ) and Amazon (AWS) both finding major cloud and AI momentum into the coming years,” he added.

headline: Elon Musk leads world's 500 richest people in 2024 as wealth grew
summary: The top 500 wealthiest individuals globally accumulated a combined net worth exceeding $10 trillion in 2024. Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk emerged as one of the year's most significant gainers, with his net worth climbing to $442.1 billion following the US presidential election, solidifying his position as the world's wealthiest person. Wealth! host Madison Mills explores this development, examining the other executives who substantially increased their fortunes throughout 2024. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Wealth here. This post was written by Angel Smith

headline: Ralph Lauren, Yum! Brands, Tesla: Market Minute
summary: Wealth host Madison Mills takes a look at the top stories on Wall Street in today's Market Minute: Argus Research analysts upgrade Ralph Lauren (RL) to Buy from Hold, citing international demand. Yum! Brands (YUM) — the parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell — also received an upgrade from Argus analysts based on strong same-store sales and artificial intelligence (AI) marketing. Tesla (TSLA) is set to release its fourth quarter delivery numbers this Thursday, January 2, 2025. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Wealth here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

headline: The S&P 500's most volatile stocks in 2024
summary: Looking back on 2024, the year saw monumental gains across the major indexes (^DJI, ^IXIC, ^GSPC) while still proving to be a roller coaster ride of volatility for several individual stocks. The Morning Brief anchors Seana Smith and Madison Mills take a look at several of the S&P 500's most volatile names in 2024, including Palantir Technologies (PLTR), Tesla (TSLA), Enphase Energy (ENPH), and Super Micro Computer (SMCI) after its shares plummeted, tied to the resignation of its auditor. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Tesla to fix software for 77,650 China-made vehicles, says market regulator
summary: Tesla will fix software in 77,650 China-made Model 3 and Model Y cars over safety hazards, China's market regulator said on Tuesday.  The action, due to software issues that may fail to display the monitored tyre pressure immediately after the vehicle starts, is described as a product recall under Chinese regulations, the regulator said.  It was not immediately clear if drivers might need, or would be eligible, to return vehicles to Tesla for refunds.

raw.headline: Tesla to fix software for 77,650 China-made vehicles, says market regulator

The action, due to software issues that may fail to display the monitored tyre pressure immediately after the vehicle starts, is described as a product recall under Chinese regulations, the regulator said.  It was not immediately clear if drivers might need, or would be eligible, to return vehicles to Tesla for refunds.

headline: EV Sales Will Tumble in 2025. What It Means for Tesla and the Rest of the Auto Industry.
summary: Investors in all car stocks, including  Tesla  should buckle up for a bumpy ride.  President-elect Donald Trump is widely expected to eliminate EV purchase tax credits worth up to $7,500 per vehicle.  If that happens, it amounts to a big price increase for most electric cars.
